title: How to Make Homemade Butterfinger Candy Bars

steps.headline: Grease a 12x17 inch jelly roll pan.
steps.description: Leave the pan in the oven until the candy is ready to be cooked. Allowing the pan to become warm (and stay warm) will allow you to have more time to spread the chocolate syrup later for the candy-bar coating.

steps.headline: Combine and place a mixture of corn syrup and water in a 2-quart saucepan.
Begin to stir the mixture together.
Add the sugar to the mixture.
Continue to cook the mixture, until it is completely clear and has reached a full boil.
Stop stirring, as you raise the temperature until it is completely clear and has reached a full rolling boil.
Test the mixture with a candy thermometer.
steps.description: Do not stop boiling the mixture until the temperature has reached 310 °F (154 °C).

steps.headline: Add the peanut butter to the (now starting to cool) mixture, while continuing to stir.
Pour the mixture into the pan, spreading as evenly as possible.
Cut to score the candied area with a knife, so it can be divided into 1x2 inch pieces.
Allow the pieces to cool at room temperature for two hours.
Refrigerate the candies to help assist you in a more thorough cool.

steps.headline: Prepare your mixture of slightly-warmed dipping chocolate.
Dip each piece of candy in the dipping chocolate.
Allow the candies to cool and refrigerate for an additional hour.

text:
Grease a 12x17 inch jelly roll pan. Leave the pan in the oven until the candy is ready to be cooked. Allowing the pan to become warm (and stay warm) will allow you to have more time to spread the chocolate syrup later for the candy-bar coating. Combine and place a mixture of corn syrup and water in a 2-quart saucepan. Begin to stir the mixture together. Add the sugar to the mixture. Continue to cook the mixture, until it is completely clear and has reached a full boil. Stop stirring, as you raise the temperature until it is completely clear and has reached a full rolling boil. Test the mixture with a candy thermometer. Do not stop boiling the mixture until the temperature has reached 310 °F (154 °C). Add the peanut butter to the (now starting to cool) mixture, while continuing to stir. Pour the mixture into the pan, spreading as evenly as possible. Cut to score the candied area with a knife, so it can be divided into 1x2 inch pieces. Allow the pieces to cool at room temperature for two hours. Refrigerate the candies to help assist you in a more thorough cool. You will remove these candies after 15-30 minutes. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/Make-Homemade-Butterfinger-Candy-Bars-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Homemade-Butterfinger-Candy-Bars-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/Make-Homemade-Butterfinger-Candy-Bars-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/aid1760337-v4-728px-Make-Homemade-Butterfinger-Candy-Bars-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Prepare your mixture of slightly-warmed dipping chocolate. Dip each piece of candy in the dipping chocolate. Allow the candies to cool and refrigerate for an additional hour.
